text:
FRANCESCA ELY-SPENCE:
I'm Francesca Ely-Spence,

and I'll be presenting my
senior thesis from college.

So I wrote my thesis on finsta
a subculture on Instagram

and how it can function as
a mental health resource.

So let's start out with
defining what finsta is.

A finsta or fake Instagram
is a separate locked account

that individuals use
to share everything

from bad selfies, emotional
rants, funny memes, any media
information.

Ironically, it's
a representation
of one's more real self.

Despite the name,
generally users

will post anything
they feel does not

belong on their real Instagram
or rinsta, which follows

more conventional codes
of conduct formulated
for social media platforms.

It's curated, superficial,
made for other people.

The specific subculture
in reference to that,

that I examined, provides
a safe space for users

to share deeply
personal information,

vent, process emotions, and
request support or advice
from their followers.

And this is an example from my
own account of posts of mine

and then comments from
people who follow me.

I use Goffmans'
theory of front stage

versus backstage
performance as a framework
for this social world.

Goffman finds front
stage as the self

that's made public and expressly
visible to an audience,

demonstrating to
the audience what it
can expect from the performer.

So in the context
of social media,

that operates through
Facebook, Snapchat, rinsta,

where the individual has to
adopt and more importantly

avoid deviating from a specific
form of self-presentation.

There are social repercussions
for deviating from that norm.

The audience expects
continuity, a single narrative

into which you can then
be compartmentalized.

By contrast, the
backstage functions

as a private space where
public image does not

need to be maintained
or protected.

To quote [? Goffman, ?]
it's a place

where the performer can
relax, drop their front,

forgo their lines, and
step out of character.
Be them self.

In Goffman's theory,
the backstage

was off limits to the
audience completely,

and that was key-- that
lack of surveillance.

But on finsta, users grant
admittance to a select few

creating a curated audience
who may then not only view

their backstage behavior but
also validate it, interact
with it, contribute to it.

So what happens when the
backstage is performed
in front of the audience?

When you combine
vulnerability and authenticity

with performance,
what do you get?

I felt this was uncharted
territory, a compelling case

study of what happens
when the backstage retains

its unfiltered features
in a more public setting.

On finsta, users still present
themselves before the audience

and are aware of the presence,
but for the most part

they use this performance
to discover and communicate

who they are rather
than who they
want others to think they are.

Instead of presenting a persona
curated to appeal to others,

users engage with a more
sincere, vulnerable form

of self-representation that
stems from their own self
concepts.

The audience's presence
and participation actually

becomes more of a vehicle for
authentic, vulnerable sharing

because users know that
the revelations will be
met with care and compassion.

In this sense,
finsta can be seen

as a moratorium, a term
coined by Erick Erickson,

for a space to freely
experiment with identity.

And in creating such a space
for trying on different personas

or senses of oneself, users
develop a remarkably intricate

modern understanding
of identity,

the notion of a
multi-dimensional fluid self.

Shaped by users, for users,
the key characteristics

of finsta culture, this communal
atmosphere, safety, security

encourages new forms of
self-exploration and identity

formation and experimentation,
both before and within
a community.

Finsta users have demonstrated
incredible agency, creativity,

and courage in creating a unique
technology-based social world.

It's complete with
its own set of norms,

ideals, values,
can and does often

serve as a sign
of vulnerability,

a secure space for
experimentation with identity.

A valuable mental
health resource.

I think we all need space
like that in a world

where we're more
and more oriented

toward branding self-image,
self-representation.

We need spaces where
we can discover

all the parts of
ourselves, and be

open to the possibility
of growth and change.

Social media is a medium
where the self is editable,

and in the context of finsta,
members choose to give it--

choose to use it to
give a voice to weakness

and what may be the
most truthful depiction
of themselves.

Maybe in this
context, courage lies

not in establishing a fixed
sense of self or static set

of principles, but in
acknowledging all the flux,

fluidity, and ambiguity
within oneself.

And doing so in
front of and even
with but not for an audience.
[APPLAUSE]
